meanings.definition: The quality of being easily eroded.
meanings.sent1: The erodibility of the sand dunes made them disappear quickly in the storm.
meanings.sent2: Farmers must consider the erodibility of the soil before planting crops.
meanings.sent3: The erodibility of the beach sand turned building sandcastles into a fun challenge.
meanings.sent4: The erodibility of the cliffs was a constant reminder of the power of nature.
meanings.sent5: The erodibility of the rocks along the riverbank created a stunning landscape over time.

meanings.definition: The susceptibility of a material to erosion.
meanings.sent1: The erodibility of the paint on the old house caused it to peel off easily.
meanings.sent2: Engineers study the erodibility of different materials to build stronger structures.
meanings.sent3: The erodibility of the sandbags made them less effective in preventing floods.
meanings.sent4: The erodibility of the metal bridge was evident in the rust that formed over time.
meanings.sent5: The erodibility of the coastline led to the gradual disappearance of the cliffs.

meanings.definition: The ability of soil to be worn away by natural forces.
meanings.sent1: The erodibility of the farmland resulted in loss of fertile soil each year.
meanings.sent2: Conservation efforts aim to reduce the erodibility of agricultural land.
meanings.sent3: The erodibility of the garden soil made it challenging to maintain flower beds.
meanings.sent4: The erodibility of the hillside was evident in the deep gullies formed by rain.
meanings.sent5: The erodibility of the riverbank soil threatened nearby homes with erosion.
